data.title: Horns (2013) Review
data.meta_description: Horns (2013) Directed by Alexandre Aja Based on Horns by Joe Hill Starring: Daniel Radcliffe, Max Minghella, Joe Anderson, Juno Temple, Kelli Garner, James Remar, Kathleen Quinlan, Heather Graham, David Morse, Sabrina Carpenter Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia) Horns is an American dark fantasy horror-comedy film directed by Alexandre Aja, loosely based on Joe Hill's novel‚Ä¶
data.text:
Horns (2013)

Directed by Alexandre Aja

Based on Horns by Joe Hill

Starring: Daniel Radcliffe, Max Minghella, Joe Anderson, Juno Temple, Kelli Garner, James Remar, Kathleen Quinlan, Heather Graham, David Morse, Sabrina Carpenter

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

Horns is an American dark fantasy horror-comedy film directed by Alexandre Aja, loosely based on Joe Hill‚Äôs novel of the same name. Daniel Radcliffe stars as a man who is accused of raping and murdering his girlfriend (Juno Temple) and uses his newly discovered paranormal abilities to uncover the real killer.

My Opinion:

Okay, so I watched this movie after reading the book because I of course wanted to see how they‚Äôd adapt such a weird story (you can read my review of the book HERE). I know that movies are rarely as good as the books but they did a pretty poor job with this adaptation. It started out pretty good, too, so it was disappointing that it fell apart.

Yes, we have Harry Potter playing Ig, a guy who grows Devil horns. And has sex! NO! Do NOT have sex, Daniel Radcliffe! That‚Äôs just really disturbing ‚Äì you‚Äôre a little kid. And Juno Temple‚Ä¶ is it just me or is that girl annoying? I suppose she wasn‚Äôt too bad in this, though, as she was kind of how I pictured Merrin. She‚Äôs famous because her dad (Julien Temple) is famous. Can we just talk about his music documentary/music video work instead? That‚Äôs far more interesting than Horns. My husband told me he likes it more when I go off on a tangent, like when I ‚Äúreviewed‚Äù Primer and ended up talking about Weebles. Really?? Surely people find that annoying! Just Google Julien Temple if you don‚Äôt know him ‚Äì besides things like his Sex Pistols documentaries, he directed far more music videos than I realized (videos for Judas Priest, The Rolling Stones, Neil Young, Depeche Mode, etc etc, and that David Bowie movie Absolute Beginners). Oh, and check out my chat with Hard Ticket To Home Video‚Äôs Brian of Billy Idol‚Äôs White Wedding video HERE (which wasn‚Äôt directed by Temple ‚Äì I‚Äôm just whoring my Music Video Friday posts that only I & two other bloggers like). üòâ

Right! Horns. I think the movie captured the love story between Ig & Merrin pretty well, which was good as that‚Äôs what I liked the most about the book. But it did a terrible job with all the other characters. As always, I won‚Äôt spoil the story but the two other biggest characters are probably Ig‚Äôs brother Terry & Ig‚Äôs friend Lee (who couldn‚Äôt look more different from how he‚Äôs described in the book). Their stories were changed quite a bit and they got no character development at all in the movie. I hated the changes as they didn‚Äôt really seem like the type that were necessary to save on time or whatever (I let some changes slide as I know it‚Äôs hard to squeeze a long book into a short movie). For those seeing the movie only, I think you‚Äôve totally missed out on most of the characters‚Äô motivations for doing the things they did.

And Heather Graham couldn‚Äôt have felt more out of place! They changed & made her role far bigger than it was in the book and I‚Äôm afraid to say that she came across as quite desperate in this & her acting was just embarrassing. It makes me sad to say that ‚Äì I kind of like Heather Graham. I‚Äôm assuming she was told to act in that way, though, as Wikipedia oddly describes Horns as a horror comedy, which I don‚Äôt think is at all accurate. There are a couple small dark comedy moments but don‚Äôt watch it expecting a dark comedy ‚Äì it‚Äôs a supernatural murder mystery horror. It‚Äôs a very unique & original story so I suppose that‚Äôs just Hollywood trying to give it a simple classification.

Despite my complaints, I did like this movie okay. I‚Äôm going to be picky as I liked the book but, trying to look at it as someone who hasn‚Äôt read the book would, I think it‚Äôs a decent enough film. It does try a little too hard to be ‚Äúcool‚Äù but I think that‚Äôs pretty common for movies aimed at twentysomethings. Yes, like Joe Hill‚Äôs books are very much aimed at a younger generation than those older fans of his dad‚Äôs (Stephen King) work, this movie very obviously knows its specific target audience. Which is fine ‚Äì I‚Äôm sure a lot of now-adults who grew up with Harry Potter love this movie. I think Daniel Radcliffe will have been chosen for this very reason & he‚Äôs much better than I was expecting ‚Äì I ended up having no issues with him playing Ig (I read on IMDB that Shia LaBeouf was originally going to play Ig. Yuck ‚Äì can you imagine?! That would‚Äôve been a huge mistake!). Also, the movie‚Äôs soundtrack is pretty good. It was out of place half the time & far too obvious sometimes (such as using Personal Jesus) but I‚Äôm not going to complain at a soundtrack including David Bowie even though the song Heroes worked much better in The Perks Of Being A Wallflower (plus David Bowie is currently the ‚Äúartist you must include in your soundtrack to make your movie seem cool‚Äú).

Summary:

Horns is a decent enough horror movie if you‚Äôre looking for a different sort of story that you‚Äôve not seen in a thousand other films (that‚Äôs usually my biggest complaint with horror movies such as Mama). Don‚Äôt get the wrong idea when I say it‚Äôs aimed at twentysomethings who grew up with Harry Potter ‚Äì it‚Äôs a dark film & very much a ‚Äúhorror‚Äù. I was surprised when looking up the director‚Äôs other work (The Hills Have Eyes remake, Mirrors, Piranha 3D(!), and the ultra-violent Switchblade Romance which has been on my list to watch for the blog every October but I still haven‚Äôt because I‚Äôm a wuss). Well, Horns is less extreme than any of those. I far preferred the book, of course, but at least they got the central love story right in the movie even if they made a mess of everything else. I‚Äôd actually recommend only watching the movie with this one if you‚Äôre not much of a book person ‚Äì you‚Äôll enjoy the movie more that way. If you are a book person, definitely read the book first.

My Rating: 6.5/10
